newsitem.title: USA: Away on Business - Internet mileposts.
newsitem.headline: Away on Business - Internet mileposts.

text.p: The Internet is brimming with raw and refined information of interest to the business traveller.
Anyone flying into a strange city, grabbing a rental car and looking for a precise route to a location knows that maps handed out at the rental counter can be short on detail.
There's help available on the Worldwide Web at www.mapquest.com -- and it's free.
The site offers driving instructions between 150,000 towns in North America as well as door-to-door driving directions for 34 metropolitan areas within the United States.

When the user enters a request for a specific door-to-door route there are written directions -- "turn left on Vine, go one block on River, right on Green Boulevard to the Interstate 90 ramp" -- as well as maps that can be printed out.

Perry Evans, president of MapQuest Publishing, a business unit of GeoSystems Global Corp., told Reuters the site gets about 80,000 requests a day for driving instructions, and about half of those are detailed point-to-point directions that are used much the same way drivers use one of those flip over map routes provided by motor clubs.
"We know that people are using us on a very regular basis for getting from point A to point B," he said. "And we want to make this a richer experience."

Their enriched information, he said, will be both consumer friendly and bring in revenue for his company. He said Radisson Hotels, as an example, recently signed up with a list of its properties which will pop up in the driving instructions any time the selected route passes within a certain distance of one of them.
There are similar possibilities for including other commercial travel information such as the location of nearby filling stations.
How long will this kind of information remain free?
Evans said he believes the service will continue to be free to consumers "at some level" for the foreseeable future.

That may be possible because of the revenue from commercials ties. The Sabre Group, for instance, recently chose MapQuest for use on its Travelocity Web site -- www.travelocity.com -- a location which describes itself as the leader in online reservation services.
Online travel may be the place to hitch a wagon.
A new report from Jupiter Communications estimates that revenues of $276 million were generated by online travel bookings last year for air, hotel, car rental, cruises and vacation packages.
It expects that figure to increase threefold this year and rise to $4.5 billion by the end of the year 2000.
